headline: Google hires Windsurf execs in $2.4 billion deal to advance AI coding ambitions
summary: (Reuters) -Alphabet's Google has hired several key staff members from AI code generation startup Windsurf, the companies announced on Friday, in a surprise move following an attempt by its rival OpenAI to acquire the startup.  Google is paying $2.4 billion in license fees as part of the deal to use some of Windsurf's technology under non-exclusive terms, according to a person familiar with the arrangement.  Google will not take a stake or any controlling interest in Windsurf, the person added.

raw.headline: Google hires Windsurf execs in $2.4 billion deal to advance AI coding ambitions
raw.summary: (Reuters) -Alphabet's Google has hired several key staff members from AI code generation startup Windsurf, the companies announced on Friday, in a surprise move following an attempt by its rival OpenAI to acquire the startup.  Google is paying $2.4 billion in license fees as part of the deal to use some of Windsurf's technology under non-exclusive terms, according to a person familiar with the arrangement.  Google will not take a stake or any controlling interest in Windsurf, the person added.

headline: Nvidia and Other Big Tech Stocks That Are Cheaper Than You Might Think
summary: Nvidia  is one of those stocks.  Nvidia  is expected to report second-quarter earnings at the end of August, but investors could get a taste of demand for the company’s hardware as other tech companies report their AI spending plans in the weeks ahead.  Meanwhile, Nvidia investors have celebrated the stock’s comeback from April lows, with share now up 21% this year.

headline: Amazon Stock Has Room to Run. 2 Analysts Raise Price Targets Before Earnings.
summary: Amazon.com  stock has had an underwhelming year, but analysts from Morgan Stanley and J.P. Morgan believe the shares have much more room to run in the months ahead.  The analysts raised their price targets, citing confidence in  Amazon’s  growth opportunities for both e-commerce and cloud computing unit AWS.  Morgan Stanley’s Brian Nowak increased his price target late Thursday from $250 to $300, which implies a 33% increase from the stock’s previous close of $226.26.

Morgan Stanley’s Brian Nowak increased his price target late Thursday from $250 to $300, which implies a 33% increase from the stock’s previous close of $226.26.

headline: Wall Street Has Faith in the TACO Trade. That’s Looking Less Wise.
summary: Traders and investors have ridden an extraordinary spring rally by betting against President Donald Trump’s myriad tariff threats,  a play known as the TACO trade, for “Trump Always Chickens Out.”  The pace of those gains is slowing, and the risk associated with hoping that the president will soften or reverse his increasingly complex tariff gambits is mounting.  Adam Turnquist, chief technical strategist at  LPL Financial  says five stocks—  Nvidia Meta Platforms Broadcom Amazon.com  and  Microsoft  —are responsible for half of the S&P 500’s 5.2% gain over the past month.

raw.headline: Wall Street Has Faith in the TACO Trade. That’s Looking Less Wise.
raw.summary: Traders and investors have ridden an extraordinary spring rally by betting against President Donald Trump’s myriad tariff threats,  a play known as the TACO trade, for “Trump Always Chickens Out.”  The pace of those gains is slowing, and the risk associated with hoping that the president will soften or reverse his increasingly complex tariff gambits is mounting.  Adam Turnquist, chief technical strategist at  LPL Financial  says five stocks—  Nvidia Meta Platforms Broadcom Amazon.com  and  Microsoft  —are responsible for half of the S&P 500’s 5.2% gain over the past month.

headline: Vertiv Stock Drops as Amazon Launches Cooling Competitor. Why These Analysts Say Buy.
summary: Vertiv Holdings  stock was dropping again Friday in response to  Amazon.com  Amazon Web Services development of a new cooling system of its own that could disrupt the leader in data-center cooling solutions.  Analysts, however, think the selloff is “overblown.”  The infrastructure can be installed in new and existing data centers designed for power-hungry artificial-intelligence computing, the company said.
